choices.text:
what is a metonymy?
A metonymy is a figure of speech in which the name of an object, concept or activity is replaced by another closely associated word or phrase. This replacement can be used to create a more vivid and concise description, often conveying a deeper meaning or emotional impact than the original term would alone. For example, instead of saying "I am thirsty," someone might say "my throat is parched" - both expressions convey the same idea but one uses a metonymic substitution (parched for thirsty).
